Okay, so let me see if this makes sense: you say you miss the old Kate -- the Kate who drinks and blacks out and has fun.
Well...here she is.
Fuck yeah you were. And what? Now you won't drink with me?
Well thanks for all the support when I was trying to be sober!
Of course you didn't realize! You don't fucking care about me.
I love you too. Love is the easy part. It's the rest of the shit that's hard.
Take off your pants.
I don't wanna sleep. I wanna fuck.
No! I want you to fuck me!
Be a man and fuck your wife!
With me? With me?! What the fuck is wrong with me? I try hard and I get shit on! Fucked up family, fired from my job -- this marriage.
What? What? What do I need? I can't drink because I'm crazy or something and I can't stay sober because of you!
I can't be sober and be with you.
You tell me.
Thanks.
Hey, I'm Kate, alcoholic.
I've heard that your best day drinking is worse than your worst day sober.
Well...that is SO not true! I had amazing times drinking, dancing, and laughing...feeling like the most adorable, charming girl in the world. And I was adorable.
I'd piss my pants, but I was still cute.
When I first tried getting sober, I figured that as long as I didn't drink...everything else would just magically work out. But it didn't.
My marriage fell apart. I got fired from my job. And that shit happened SOBER! I never read that in any pamphlet...
...that isn't what I signed up for.
Um...so, I relapsed. Another shitty slogan I've heard in the rooms is that when you're sober for a bit and drink again "the disease waits for you, picks up where it left off."
I'm sorry you guys, but I HATE those slogans. They all sound like bumper stickers. But, I have to admit...for me, that last one is pretty damn true.
When I drink...I become another person. And that person is a pretty big asshole. Well, unless you want to give me drugs or buy me drinks --
I wasn't happy being the "good-time girl," though. And honestly, I wasn't very good at it.
My life is really different than it was a year ago. I live alone. I'm bored a lot more. I have a job that pays a lot less.
I'm thankful for the program -- for my friends in here who took the time to help me and give a shit about me.
There are people that used to be a part of my life that I miss -- a lot -- but...
...I'm really grateful for this boring new life of mine.
Um...yeah. Sometimes.
Sometimes.
I've been sober for a year.
Yeah.
Yeah. A couple of days ago.
Charlie...
No.
I don't think it's a good idea.
Charlie, please don't do this.
I don't like shitty 80's music.
I like good 80's music.
You look really thin.
When did you last eat?
Should we order something?
I don't know. I haven't really been doing the meat thing.
Fine. Bacon and egg sandwiches. But I'm gonna make them.
I don't care if you drink a beer.
Yeah. Whatever.
I haven't played in over a year.
I don't know. Innate talent?
Um...stick to the game, okay?
Charlie --
Stop it.
You could've been killed.
Riding your bike -- drunk.
But is that really the point?
I worry about you.
You should go for yourself, not to make me happy.
I'm not moving back in.
Listen, I should go. It's gonna get dark soon.
I don't know...
Yeah -- I've been trying to flirt with the bartender, but...I can't tell.
She looks like she could kick my ass. No way would she go for a guy like me.
I don't know...forget about it.
Yeah.
I know it sounds silly, but I feel responsible for them -- like...
...I could be their parent.
She's seen "Say Anything."
Yeah, man -- you don't have a job to wake up for in the morning or anything.
It did.
-- Durham -- playing minor league ball. I had some real heat. That's when I met Crash, here.
He'd been sent down to single-A to teach me how to carry myself as a pro ball-player. We got involved with the same woman -- an older chick -- but Crash won her in the end.
He's really taught me some...important life-lessons.
Yeah. It is.
I don't know. Which one?
Do you know what movie she means?
So, Crash -- why don't you tell this nice lady about the 21 days you were up in "The Show," and what the crowds were like, and --
Yeah, he'll be fine -- on his bicycle.
Oh, yeah --
-- as a teenager, he was a bike racing champion growing up in Bloomington, Indiana. He and his friends were called the "Cutters" --
Back then, I was a kickboxing instructor...
The bartender quickly pours the drinks.
That's fifteen.
What happened?
You kickbox?
Yeah. Are you?
Good.
Hey, I'm not really okay.
My bitch sister just took off and left me here so she could hook up with some asshole. Now what am I supposed to do? Huh? I don't have a car here.
You'll give me a ride? Oh my god!
It's not far. Please? Pretty please...?
You know, you shouldn't drink and drive.
Just kidding. Can I have a sip?
I'm really thirsty.
Fuck yeah, it's whiskey! I love whiskey. You're the real thing, huh? A hardcore drinking bitch like me!
Can I smoke in your car?
Of course -- I'm not uncivilized.
Want a hit?
Of course not! What do I look like?
It's crack.
C'mon -- it's good crack.
Really? This stuff is the truth --
night?
Seriously? It's not a big deal --
One hit won't hurt you. It'll sober you up.
Smoke me!
You've got money, right?

Characters.Character: PARKING LOT AT AN ELEMENTARY SCHOOL

Replies.Reply: She's about to get out, but then notices...
"Hurry up in there -- I gotta use the can!"
That's a name for a man -- not a baby!
P.
Um...pan?
Are you?
Are you gonna have a boy or a girl?
If you have a boy what will you name him?
EW! GRODY! GROSS! YUCK! IT SMELLS LIKE CHEESE! SLOPPY JOE! GRANDPA!
Vice Principal Davies will be looking after your students for the rest of the day -- so you don't need to worry about that.
Oh, please -- they're troopers. I'm sure they've seen plenty worse.
So -- how long have you been pregnant?
Well, it's very exciting. You must be thrilled.
Can I ask a...personal question?
How's it...
...going for you?
The pregnancy, I mean.
Having kids wasn't in the cards for me. I came close, but...
...I mean, it's like I've got a couple hundred kids here --
-- but...I don't fool myself. It's not the same.
Of course...
It's a responsibility.
You're so lucky.
Can I...touch it?
Of course.
Hello in there. Can you hear me?
I can only imagine the chemistry experiment that's going on --
-- in there.
Mrs. Hannah -- I've got something for you...
Folic Acid! You need it now like never before.
I bet your mother is over the moon, huh? Probably planning you a baby shower...?
here, okay?
Now drink up -- that baby in there's thirsty!
My lips are --
I couldn't keep quiet. Sorry. I just had to tell everyone so we could celebrate.
You don't have to thank me -- just open your presents!
Go ahead.
It's to hang over the crib!
Mmmm...it's so moist.
I'm so sorry, Kate.
I haven't told many people this, but when I was young -- younger than you...I lost a child too.
It's okay. It was a long, long time ago. Still hurts sometimes. But eventually...you move on. You have to.
Have a seat.
I got a phone call from a very upset parent. That's how I found out about...you know. Frankly, I'm not sure why you didn't feel like you could tell me.
I'm not angry with you -- but I need to be clear that this doesn't happen again.
By "not happening again," I mean that you don't discuss any controversial topics -- things the school board deems "family matters"
I know this all must be hard for you --
What do you mean?
But...you vomited in class.
Oh, my god -- are you really ill?
What?
You vomited in front of children because you were hung over?
And lied, saying that you were pregnant?
That's sick, Kate.
No, I don't think you understand how wrong that is. To lie to me --
Jesus...you told us you had a miscarriage.
I threw you a baby shower.
I'm sorry, but what you did is totally irresponsible.
I can't have you here anymore.
No, no -- the state wouldn't allow that without a report. I'm not going to write a report. Because, frankly, I have no idea what that report would say.
But I'm forcing you to take a leave of absence and I think it's in your best interest if you find a job elsewhere.
I believe you -- or I want to. I really do. But honey -- I believed you before.
I'll have a sub take over your class starting tomorrow. It's late enough in the year that we can just say you're having personal problems --
-- which seems to be the truth.
Not another word. I'm upset right now -- very upset -- and I think I'm doing you a favor by not reporting you.
Hey, I'm Donovan. Welcome.
You must be a newcomer, huh?
Um, I'm not really allowed to talk to new chicks, but there are lots of women here who can help you out.
The meeting already started so just try to find a spot anywhere.
Not to embarrass anyone, but so that we may get to know you better -
a drink or any mind-altering substance in the past 24 hours.
Welcome, Kate.
It gets better.
Thank you -- we're all here to help. We do have to move on, though.
Hey, I'm Amber, alcoholic. I can't really believe that it's been five years. I mean, my life was a mess back then. Now I'm back in school, I have an amazing man, I love my parents -- it's crazy...
Um...okay? It's because I did the work. I got down on my knees and prayed every night! I went to a meeting everyday!
It wasn't easy, but I've gotta say, I owe everything to AA. Well, AA --
God grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change --
Hi, Kate.
Congratulations.
You know I can't sell you this, Kate.
Yes, I do, Kate. And I know you're old enough -- but it's too late.
Stop it.
I don't think so. Sorry.
It's the law. I can't sell alcohol after 2 a.m. You know that.
I could lose my job.
Look -- why don't you get a bottle of water or a coffee or something instead?
Oh my god. Okay, enough -- you gotta go.
Seriously, Kate. You should go.
What the fuck are you doing?!
Get outta here NOW!
Hi, Kate.
Hi, Kate.
S'minute!
Katie!
What're you doing here?
Oh, you know I don't check that thing.
Well, then...
...what a lovely surprise -- you two came to visit. Hell has frozen over.
Just kidding. Come inside -- let me fix you both some drinks.
...you wouldn't believe how much the neighborhood's changed! After Mr. Baker passed away and the kids put Mrs. Baker in a home, the people that moved in, oof!
It's like they don't even understand the concept of birth control in their country!
If you ask me, I think it's a meth house.
They've always got those little five year old twins "playing" in the yard, but I'm pretty sure they're the lookouts.
Right?
Oh, please! Where I'm from, "no"
Are you telling me I'm going to be a grandma?
Oh -- that's so exciting! I'm gonna be a grandma!
And you know that "no drinking when you're pregnant" thing is just a myth. I drank plenty when I was pregnant with Kate -- and look how she turned out!
Oh.
Well...
...we'll see how long that lasts.
You've sure picked the right partner --
-- for this little mission.
Ah...yes. Assholes Anonymous.
Katie's father went to those meetings a few years after we got married. Dried up. Left me. You can see how well that worked out for me...
...I raised his daughter in this PALACE while he's somewhere in Florida with his shiny new wife and kids.
Bastard.
Oh...I'm sorry -- I'm not being a good hostess, am I?
I'll microwave you your favorite.
I'm sorry if I acted like a bitch.
SURPRISE!
what I got you! Is it a boy or a girl?
OOOH!
Mrs. Hannah -- are you going to hell?
What do you need?
Sure -- you gotta pay for the first one, though. Eight bucks.
you've had a bad day, but um... I think you need to go home.
Cause you're pretty drunk -- and it's four p.m.
I'm just trying to be a pal.
Oh, boy...
Wow, okay, well...I'm real sorry.
Lady, you're done.
No.
Not in the slightest.
I think it's time for you to go home. Now are you gonna let me call a cab?
You do that.
Hope that works out for you.
Wow...that's a pretty crazy way to meet.
You guys are sorta like that movie...what's it called?
"Bull"...something? What is it?
Whatever. It'll come to me.
Really?
Like what?
You were talking about writing for websites and you kinda trailed off, honey.
You want a ride...?
Um...is he cool to drive?
He rides a bicycle?
